channel.title: This would be a great Destruct-O-Match II Script
channel.description:
It would take probably a very time, but imagine this as the grid *points down*
x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x x
For the bottom left x, and the one just to the right of that, you would look for an orange colour. Like ( if(findcolor(x,y,12389,24,56,948,383)) and (findcolor(x,y,12389,53,64,284,494)), and then for the next set of squares, and so on. Then copy and paste that code, and change the "12389" to the color for blue in all of them, and then green etc..
This would take a very long time but would be much less detectable, and get a much better score :) - Also, remember to add in wait times so it doesnt freeze.[br][size=1]Posted on: May 12, 2007, 03:44:16 PM[/size][hr]Lol @ replying to my own topic like 1 min after :) But, I'm gonna try to make this, it shouldnt be too hard - but I'll race someone to finish it if they like :)

item.title: This would be a great Destruct-O-Match II Script
item.dc:creator: @dudeofthed dudeofthed
item.description:
@dudeofthed wrote:

aznph8playa:

No problem, btw there is a pretty decent destructo script working right now, maybe you should try playing with that and color tolerances? (Color tolerances are used to find colors that are similar but changed)

I made one with bitmaps. But didn’t work out because it was clicking on the highest boulder from the top of my screen it could find.
There is a very good one already out there that uses co-ordinates.

Read full topic
item.source: This would be a great Destruct-O-Match II Script

item.title: This would be a great Destruct-O-Match II Script
item.dc:creator: @oranges12233 oranges12233
item.description:
@oranges12233 wrote:

aznph8playa:

Nice thought but actually, neopets uses color changers so that the different colors may not be detectable to the eyes but they would mess up a program. There have already been programs that have used findcolor to find the same color in any two locations that have become obsolete.

Ahh I never knew that… thanks

Read full topic
